Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 52204-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
November 2018 
 
 
 
 
Towards Effective and Sustainable Delivery of 
Development Results in Fragile Situations in the 
Pacific 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
FCAS  –  fragile and conflict-affected situations 
O&M  –  operation and maintenance 
SIDS  –  small island developing states 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to United States dollars.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 19112018164033709088 Generated Date: 04-Jan-2019 12:55:17 PM  Page 2 of 2

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Strategy 2030 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) recognizes the distinct development 
challenges of fragile and conflict-affected situations (FCAS) and small island developing states 
(SIDS), and promotes a differentiated approach to these groups of developing member countries 
(DMCs).1 Under Strategy 2030, ADB will prioritize its support by providing long-term financing and 
capacity-development assistance to help build resilience and address causes of fragility or 
conflict.2 The differentiated approach under ADB’s Strategy 2030 will build on ADB’s long-
standing support for development in FCAS, which emphasizes the importance of understanding 
the local context, making a long-term commitment to development, ensuring country ownership, 
and being flexible in responding to challenges.3 
 
2.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  improving  the 
development effectiveness and sustainability of ADB operations in fragile situations to help build 
resilience and address the causes of fragility in the Pacific. It will build on the research and 
capacity-development activities delivered under previous FCAS TA projects, and lessons from 
their implementation. Through a series of country assessments, the TA will map out sources of 
fragility in FCAS countries and identify issues and constraints in the project cycle, including 
procurement. Based on these assessments as well as a review of ongoing and completed projects, 
the TA will determine practical measures to improve future approaches, such as using a single 
consultant  for  individual  projects,  climate-proofing  infrastructure,  and  including  dedicated 
operation and maintenance (O&M) funding.4 The TA will also facilitate capacity-building and 
institutional-strengthening activities that respond to the specific needs of fragile situations and 
help build resilience. A flagship knowledge-sharing event on fragility-sensitive approaches to 
development in the Pacific will provide for an exchange of experiences, lessons, and best 
practices. 
 
3.  A concept paper for this TA, with a budget of $500,000 from ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Special  Fund  (TASF  6),  was  approved  on  31  August  2018.5 The  TA  is  in  line  with  the 
implementation priorities of ADB’s Pacific Approach 2016–2020 and is included in ADB’s regional 
operations business plan, Pacific 2019–2021.6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  ADB has been expanding its assistance to fragile situations in the Pacific, all of which are 
SIDS. The active portfolio for the current Pacific FCAS countries has grown from $647 million in 
                                                
1  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila 
(July). ADB follows the United Nations definition of SIDS, which defines SIDS as all states that participate in the 
Alliance of Small Island States. Therefore, all 14 Pacific ADB DMCs are classified as SIDS. 
2  As of June 2018, nine DMCs are classified by ADB as FCAS, two of which are affected by conflict (Afghanistan and 
Myanmar), while the remaining seven are Pacific SIDS and demonstrate the effects of fragility: Kiribati, the Marshall 
Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, Nauru, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, and Tuvalu. Additionally, 
both Timor-Leste and Vanuatu had country performance assessment scores just slightly above the 3.2 cutoff for 
FCAS, and ADB’s operations in these countries continue to pay due attention to issues of fragility. 
3  ADB. 2013. Operational Plan for Enhancing ADB’s Effectiveness in Fragile and Conflict-Affected Situations. Manila; 
and ADB. 2013. Midterm Review of Strategy 2020: Meeting the Challenges of a Transforming Asia and Pacific. 
Manila. 
4  The potential application of ADB’s new financial products and instruments in FCAS countries will be assessed. 
5  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 12 September 2018. 
6  ADB. 2016. Pacific Approach 2016–2020. Manila; ADB. 2018; Regional Operations Business Plan: Pacific 2019–
2021. Manila.

2 
2010 to $1,57 billion at the end of 2017.7 ADB has strengthened the capacity of implementing and 
executing agencies on fragility-sensitive approaches to project development and implementation, 
including through TA support.8 Pacific initiatives such as the Pacific Project Improvement Action 
Plan, which was implemented as part of Pacific Approach 2016–2020, have helped improve 
project performance and deliver better results, including by strengthening project readiness and 
increasing implementation support. These efforts, combined with simplified business processes, 
have produced some encouraging results. For example, the share of infrastructure projects that 
were procurement-ready at approval in fragile situations increased from 0% in 2015 to 50% in 
2016, and 67% in 2017.9 
 
5.  Despite some positive signs, success rates of projects in fragile situations in the Pacific 
remain considerably lower than ADB’s overall project success rates; 64% of completed projects 
in fragile situations were rated successful during the 2014–2017 period, while 75% of all ADB 
sovereign projects were rated successful during the same period.10 Ensuring that the outputs and 
outcomes of ADB-financed operations in fragile situations are sustainable remains a critical 
challenge, with only 53% of completed projects rated likely sustainable during the 2014–2017 
period. The performance of ongoing projects in fragile situations was also significantly lower than 
the ADB average, with 61% of projects in fragile situations rated on track compared with the ADB 
average of 73% as of 2017. The main cause of poor project performance is limited government 
capacity for project design, implementation, and O&M. Challenges related to limited government 
capacity, both in terms of number of staff and their skills, are common to most Pacific fragile 
situations.11 Furthermore, ADB’s business processes and requirements are not always suitable 
or practical for fragile situations. 
 
6.  Improving  ADB’s  development  effectiveness  in  fragile  situations  requires  a  detailed 
understanding of the sources of fragility and a differentiated approach, with new and innovative 
solutions that help build resilience. Traditional approaches to building capacity and strengthening 
institutions have had mixed success, while standard business processes limit the ability to adapt 
project design, implementation, and O&M arrangements to the special needs of fragile situations 
in the Pacific. The suitability of new approaches—such as using a single consultant for individual 
projects and including dedicated O&M funding, which are being implemented on a pilot basis in 
the Pacific—needs to be further assessed for fragile situations. Increased collaboration with other 
development partners in the Pacific is also needed when working in fragile situations. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  effectiveness  and  sustainability  of 
development results in fragile situations in the Pacific increased.12 The TA will have the following 
                                                
7  For all FCAS-related computations, this concept paper uses the 2018 grouping of seven Pacific countries currently 
classified as FCAS (footnote 2). 
8  ADB. 2014. Technical Assistance for Mapping Resilience to Fragility and Conflict in Asia and the Pacific. Manila; and 
ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance for Building Project Implementation in the Pacific. Manila. 
9  Project design advances, results-based loans, and policy-based loans are excluded from the computation. There 
were two infrastructure projects in ADB DMCs in the Pacific classified as FCAS approved in 2015, four in 2016, and 
three in 2017. 
10  ADB. 2018. 2017 Development Effectiveness Review. Manila; estimates are based on the success rates of 
completed operations in DMCs classified as FCAS in 2017, validated by ADB’s Independent Evaluation Department. 
11 Fragile situations in the Pacific are characterized by low institutional capacity, and often a state’s weak capacity to 
carry out the basic functions of governing; their small and remote nature; and their vulnerability to climate change 
and economic, environmental, and disaster-related shocks. 
12 Defined by the TA.

3 
outcome: design, implementation, and O&M of ADB-financed operations in fragile situations 
improved.13 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Fragility assessments and project reviews in fragile situations conducted 
and findings shared. The TA will map out the root causes of fragility in FCAS countries in the 
Pacific, assess current responses by governments and ADB, and propose new solutions. By 
focusing on specific aspects of the project cycle, such as procurement policies and practices, new 
approaches  and  guidelines  will  be  tailored  to  the  unique  circumstances  found  in  fragile 
situations.14 The  assessments  will  also  consider  how  ADB  practices  and  approaches  can 
contribute to reducing gender inequality. The TA will support reviews of current and completed 
operations to identify approaches that have or have not worked well in fragile situations, and 
determine more suitable alternatives. The findings from such assessments and reviews will be 
used as inputs for capacity-development and institutional-strengthening activities that reflect new 
processes and practices for working in fragile situations. Assessment findings, training materials, 
and guidelines will be disseminated using a range of media, including printed brochures and 
online videos. The TA will also provide direct support to ongoing projects to develop fragility-
sensitive solutions to problems that are encountered. 
 
9.  Output 2: Capacity building and institutional strengthening on fragility-sensitive 
approaches to development conducted. The TA will support capacity-building activities for 
government  officials  and  development  practitioners,  including  ADB  staff,  to  gain  a  deeper 
understanding of issues and challenges when engaging in fragile situations and practical solutions 
to  addressing  these  challenges.  The  TA  will  also  facilitate  the  preparation  of  institutional-
strengthening and capacity-building plans. The capacity-building and institutional-strengthening 
activities will be implemented in collaboration with other bilateral and multilateral development 
partners in the Pacific and will include lessons from their work. To overcome the logistical and 
resource constraints of reaching out to more participants, ADB will update and develop online 
learning  courses  that  cater  to  different  knowledge  levels  and  provide  on-demand  learning 
opportunities. To facilitate more coordinated approaches to working in fragile situations and better 
sharing of experiences, the TA will also support the organization of a flagship event on fragility-
sensitive approaches to development in the Pacific. This event will bring together representatives 
of DMCs, bilateral and multilateral development partners; and will build on the momentum of the 
ADB Annual Meeting 2019 in Fiji. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 
2. The TA will cover the travel costs of ADB staff acting as resource persons for seminars and 
workshops. The funds for this TA might be replenished during implementation subject to demand 
for the TA activities. 
 
11.  The governments of participating DMCs will make relevant country data available; will 
nominate participants to join capacity-building activities and meetings related to this TA; will 
validate  TA  deliverables,  such  as  country  and  progress  reports;  and  may  provide  in-kind 
contributions. 
                                                
13 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
14 ADB. 2018. Fragile, Conflict-Affected and Emergency Situations. Guidance Notes on Procurement. Manila.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will be the executing agency of the TA. ADB’s Pacific Department will administer and 
implement the TA. Because of the complexities and risks inherent in the operating environments 
found in fragile situations, the TA will be implemented over a 39-month period, from 1 December 
2018 to 28 February 2022. The TA will support (i) fragility needs assessments, focusing on the 
specific areas of project cycles, country needs assessments that map the root causes of fragility, 
and  project  reviews;  and  (ii)  the  development  of  e-learning  courses  on  fragility-sensitive 
approaches  to  development,  capacity-building  and  institutional-strengthening  activities,  and 
organization of a flagship event on fragility-sensitive approaches to development in the Pacific. 
 
13.  The TA will disseminate knowledge through various platforms. To ensure continuous 
learning on fragility-sensitive approaches, e-learning courses will be developed to provide on-
demand learning opportunities. These courses may be hosted on existing ADB platforms for 
online learning to ensure that they remain accessible following TA closure. In collaboration with 
ADB’s  Department  of  Communications,  the  outputs  of  country  needs  and  fragility  needs 
assessments will be disseminated through various channels, depending on the target audience. 
All outputs will be made freely available to the public through ADB's corporate website. Limited 
copies will be produced for general dissemination and targeted workshops in headquarters, 
representative offices, and resident missions. 
 
14.  The TA will require a total of 32 person-months of intermittent individual consultant 
services,  including  12  person-months  of  international  and  20  person-months  of  national 
consultant services. Consultant inputs will be required to conduct research and assessments, 
draft  brochures,  and  prepare  and  deliver  capacity-building  and  institutional-strengthening 
activities, including online training modules.

15.  Consulting  services.  Consultants  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  the  ADB 
Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time), its associated staff instructions for 
ADB-administered projects, and related project administration instructions.15 Disbursements will 
be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
                                                
15 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

5 
amended from time to time). Consultants will be required to submit quarterly progress reports and 
final reports to ADB. Evaluation of their performance will also be based on the findings of 
assessments by ADB. 
 
16.  Social media and websites. To ensure accessibility of the learning courses beyond the 
TA completion date, ADB’s Pacific Department will explore hosting the proposed e-learning 
courses within learning management system maintained by the Knowledge Sharing and Services 
Center under ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department. ADB makes 
learning courses on select development topics available to external participants on its k-Learn 
and Development Asia websites. The site provides online courses on various sector and thematic 
areas as part of ADB’s work to share knowledge in the region. ADB’s Pacific Department will work 
with the Knowledge Sharing and Services Center’s team of e-learning specialists to update and 
manage the content of the courses. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Towards Effective and Sustainable Delivery of Development Results in Fragile Situations in the 
Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Fragility assessments and project reviews in fragile situations conducted and findings shared 
1.1.  Engage international and national consultants to undertake research and assessments and prepare 
brochures and online videos (December 2018–January 2021). 
1.2.  Conduct desk research (December 2018–February 2021). 
1.3  Conduct consultations with project officers and staff of implementing and executing agencies 
(February–June 2019). 
1.4.  Identify and document lessons and good practices from operations in fragile situations (February–
December 2019). 
1.5.  Conduct country assessment mapping out sources of fragility (February 2019–June 2021). 
1.6.  Conduct fragility assessments focusing on project cycle (February 2019–December 2021). 
1.7.  Refine ADB approaches to working in fragile situations (February 2019–December 2021). 
 
2. Capacity building and institutional strengthening on fragility-sensitive approaches to 
development conducted 
2.1.  Engage international and national consultants to deliver capacity building and institutional 
strengthening, and develop online learning courses (January 2019). 
2.2.  Develop training materials, including a gender-responsive e-learning module (February 2019–
December 2019). 
2.3.  Deliver capacity-building and institutional-strengthening activities, giving special attention to gender 
inequality (July 2019–December 2021) 
2.4. Organize a flagship event on fragility-sensitive approaches to development in the Pacific (March 
2020). 
 
TA Management Activities 
Continue regular reporting and supervision until Q4 2021. 
Manage contracts from Q4 2018 until Q4 2021. 
Ensure preparation of timely progress and financial reports until Q4 2021.
